awd_abstract_narration:
A core goal in the mathematical areas Algebraic Geometry and Commutative Algebra deals with understanding the solutions of a system of polynomial equations, possibly in a large number of variables and with a large number of equations. The solution set forms a geometric object. The main idea is to study the rich and beautiful interplay between its geometric and algebraic properties. Closely related to this is the concept of a free resolution, which was introduced by the famous mathematician David Hilbert in two papers in 1890 and 1893. Constructing a free resolution amounts to repeatedly solving systems of polynomial equations. The study of these objects flourished in the second half of the twentieth century, and has seen spectacular progress recently. The field is very broad, with strong connections and applications to other mathematical areas and string theory. Recent computational methods have made it possible to compute some free resolutions by computer. 
 
The main research goal in this project is to make significant progress in understanding the structure of free resolutions and their numerical invariants. The main research topics are:
(1)  The structure of minimal free resolutions of binomial edge ideals  with a quadratic initial ideal in a polynomial ring. The project is inspired by a conjecture of Ene, Herzog, and Hibi, that the graded  Betti numbers of such an ideal coincide with the graded Betti numbers of its quadratic initial ideal (with respect to the lex order). 
(2)   The structure of infinite minimal free resolutions of lexicographic ideals in Clements-Lindstrom quotient rings, which will be studied using the methods recently introduced by Eisenbud and Peeva in their research monograph "Minimal free resolutions over complete intersections”.
(3)  The PI plans to explore a new area of research: minimal free resolutions of binomial edge ideals over exterior algebras. 

The PI plans to train graduate students in her research field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A core goal in the mathematical areas Algebraic Geometry and Commutative Algebra deals with understanding the solutions of a system of polynomial equations, possibly in a large number of variables and with a large number of equations. The solutions form a geometric object. The main idea is to study the rich and beautiful interplay between its geometric and algebraic properties. Closely related to this is the concept of free resolution, which was introduced by the famous mathematician D. Hilbert. Constructing a free resolution amounts to repeatedly solving systems of polynomial equations. Recent computational methods have made it possible to compute finite free resolutions by computer.

Free resolutions are a core area in Commutative Algebra. They also appear in Algebraic Geometry, Invariant Theory, Computational Algebra, Non-commutative Algebra, and Number Theory.  If the ground ring is graded, there exist minimal free resolutions. Hilbert showed that the minimal free resolution of any finitely generated module over a polynomial ring is finite. The condition of minimality is important: without it, resolutions are not unique, and thus invariants (like the Betti numbers) cannot be well-defined. This project deals with minimal free resolutions when there is additional structure coming from a graph. 

The PI worked on minimal free resolutions of binomial edge ideals. To a graph G we associate its binomial edge ideal J, generated by quadratic binomials in a polynomial ring. Such ideals were introduced as a generalization of ideals of minors. Their study started by Herzog, Hibi, Hreinsdotir, Kahle, Rauh, and Ohtani in 2010. Closed graphs are of interest because they characterize quadratic Grobner basis: J has a quadratic Grobner basis with respect to some term order if and only if the graph G is closed. Furthermore, if G is closed, then J has a quadratic lex Grobner basis. Suppose G is closed, and denote by M the lex initial ideal of J. Since M is an initial ideal, its Betti numbers are greater or equal to those of J. In 2011, Ene, Herzog, and Hibi conjectured that the Betti numbers of J and the Betti numbers of M are the same. Typically, the Betti numbers of an ideal are strictly smaller than those of an initial ideal; an equality is extremely rare. The conjecture by Ene, Herzog, and Hibi is striking for two reasons: (1) it predicts that the rare property of equality holds for all binomial edge ideals with a quadratic Grobner basis (which is a very large class of ideals); (2) this is a situation when the minimal free resolutions of J and M are very far from linear and can have very high regularity. The conjecture was known to hold in very few cases: Ene, Herzog, and Hibi proved it in the Cohen-Macaulay case; the extremal Betti numbers coincide by a result of Conca and Varbaro; it was known that the linear Betti numbers coincide, in particular the conjecture holds when G is a clique. Peeva proved the conjecture in full generality.

The PI has been working on Koszul graded Mobius algebras, jointly with LaClair, Mastroeni, and McCullough. Koszul algebras are important objects with extraordinary homological properties. They appear in Commutative Algebra, Algebraic Geometry, Combinatorics, Non-commutative Algebra, Topology, and other mathematical fields. Koszul algebras were introduced by Priddy in 1970, who considered more general situation which included the non-commutative case. Consider a polynomial ring T over a field k, and let J be a homogeneous ideal in T. The graded algebra T/J is Koszul if k has a linear free resolution. We deal with algebras that arise from matroids. Let M be a simple matroid with finite ground set. The graded Mobius algebra B(M) has grading induced by the rank function of the lattice of flats. Such algebras were introduced by Braden-Huh-Matherne-Proudfoot-Wang as an algebraic tool for resolving the longstanding Dowling-Wilson Top Heavy Conjecture concerning the numbers of flats of a given rank in a matroid. By construction, the Hilbert function of B(M) records exactly the number of flats of M of a given a rank, called the Whitney numbers of the second kind. The graded Mobius algebra of M embeds as a subalgebra of its augmented Chow ring, and the proof of the Top-Heavy Conjecture interpolates between the combinatorics of the graded Mobius algebra and the algebraic properties of the augmented Chow ring. The question of the Koszul property of graded Mobius algebras was raised by Ferroni-Matherne-Stevens-Vecchi. The PI, jointly with LaClair, Mastroeni, and McCullough, studied the case of graphic matroids, where to a graph G we associate its cycle matroid M(G). They proved that the graded Mobius algebra B(G) of M(G) is quadratic if and only if the graph G is chordal. Being quadratic is a necessary condition for being Koszul. Their main result is that if B(G) is Koszul, then the graph G is strongly chordal.
